issues.description: Contradiction about the SealSaloon.stock field: one part of the problem text asks students to initialize the stock in the SealSaloon constructor (implying an instance final field), while a later explicit requirement states that the stock attribute must be static (shared across all instances). These statements conflict — a static final shared stock cannot be sensibly described as being initialized per-instance in the constructor. This ambiguity can confuse students about whether to declare stock as an instance final field (initialized in the constructor) or as a static (class) field, and may cause incorrect implementations or failing tests that expect a shared/static stock.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the specification consistent: explicitly state that orders is an instance field initialized in the constructor, and that stock must be a static (shared) field (e.g., `private static final Stock stock = new Stock();`) initialized at declaration or in a static initializer. Remove or rewrite any wording that instructs students to initialize the shared stock in the instance constructor.

issues.description: Visibility mismatch for acceptSupplyDelivery(): the UML and textual specification show it as a public method (+acceptSupplyDelivery), but the solution implements it with package-private visibility (no access modifier). This difference may confuse students about the intended API and could lead to test access/visibility issues if tests expect a public static method.
issues.suggested_fix: Align visibility with the UML/specification by declaring the method as public static (e.g., `public static void acceptSupplyDelivery(String name, int price, int quantity)`). Alternatively, if package-private is intentional, update the UML/spec text to show package-private visibility so students are not misled.
